Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking whether the author of the AITA post is in the wrong after breaking up with his girlfriend over her K-pop obsession.

First, the relationship is young—both 18, been dating a month. The main issue is her fangirling over Jung Yong Hwa. The author says he tried to be understanding, even okay with the tattoo. The breaking point was when she said she'd go to the concert even if he was in the hospital. He felt betrayed, called her a psycho, and ended things.

Is he in the wrong? Well, relationships are about mutual respect and compatibility. The author felt her fangirling crossed a line when it came to prioritizing a celebrity over their relationship. But was his reaction appropriate? Breaking up over one statement, especially in a short relationship, might be seen as impulsive. However, if this was a culmination of her behavior, maybe he had enough. 

On the other hand, her answer was a shock because she was completely serious. Maybe he should have addressed it earlier instead of waiting for the breaking point. But he did mention trying to be understanding. The key here is whether her actions were a dealbreaker for him. If he felt it represented a lack of respect or commitment to their relationship, then his decision might be justified. Still, the abruptness and the harsh words ("psycho") could be seen as harsh. 

But considering the context, if he felt this was a dealbreaker and he couldn't handle it, then he's not wrong. Relationships require both parties to be on the same page. If she wasn't willing to consider his feelings, then ending it was his right. So, the answer might be B (No, he's not in the wrong) because he acted based on his own boundaries, even if the reaction was intense. Alternatively, some might argue he should have communicated better. But since he did try to be understanding and this was the last straw, B makes sense.
